en.title: Do you agree that the courts of England and Wales have jurisdiction?

cya.agree: Do you agree that the courts of England and Wales have jurisdiction?
cya.reason: Why don't you agree that the court has jurisdiction?
cya.country: In which country is your life mainly based?

en.summary: Your {{ session.divorceWho }} has stated that the court has jurisdiction (the legal power) to grant you a divorce because:
en.question: Just one of these gives the court jurisdiction.
en.jurisdictionConnectionBothResident: both you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} are habitually resident
en.jurisdictionConnectionOneResides: you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} were both last habitually resident and one of you still lives here
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitioner: your {{ session.divorceWho }}  is habitually resident and has lived here for at least 12 months
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitionerSixMonth: your {{ session.divorceWho }} is domiciled and habitually resident and has lived here for at least 6 months
en.jurisdictionConnectionBothDomiciled: both you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} are domiciled
en.jurisdictionConnectionOther: The courts of England and Wales have residual jurisdiction

habitualResidence.heading: Habitual residence
habitualResidence.summary1: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you're what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
habitualResidence.summary2: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
habitualResidence.summary3: The examples above aren't a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.

domicile.heading: Domicile
domicile.summary1: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
domicile.summary2: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
domicile.summary3Part1: When you're born, you acquire a
domicile.summary3SubText1: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
domicile.summary3SubText2: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
domicile.summary4Part1: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your
domicile.summary5: If you're not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.

residualJurisdiction.heading: Residual Jurisdiction
residualJurisdiction.intro1: The court may have residual jurisdiction if none of the other connections apply, and both of the following are true:
residualJurisdiction.bullet1: either you or your {{ session.divorceWho }} are domiciled in England or Wales
residualJurisdiction.bullet2: neither you nor your {{ session.divorceWho }} are able to apply (on the basis of your nationality or residence) for a divorce in another member state of the EU
residualJurisdiction.intro2: In addition, if you're married to a person of the same sex, the court may have residual jurisdiction if all the following apply:
residualJurisdiction.bullet3: you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} married each other in England or Wales
residualJurisdiction.bullet4: neither you nor your {{ session.divorceWho }} are able to apply for a divorce in any other country
residualJurisdiction.bullet5: it would be in the interests of justice for the court to consider the application (for example, this may apply if you or your {{ session.divorceWho }}'s home country doesn’t allow divorce between same-sex couples).

agree.heading: Yes, I agree that the court has jurisdiction

disagree.heading: No, I don't agree that the court has jurisdiction
disagree.reason: Why don't you agree that the court has jurisdiction?
disagree.country: In which country is your life mainly based?

errors.required: Select ‘Yes’ if you agree to the jurisdiction
errors.reasonRequired: Provide a reason for why you don’t agree that the court has jurisdiction
errors.countryRequired: Enter the country which you mainly live in
